Award.AwardTitle: STEM and ICT Instructional Worlds: The 3D Experience (STEM-ICT 3D)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
A coalition of Carolina universities, school districts, state agencies, and businesses called the Carolinas Virtual World Consortium are promoting the use of 3 dimensional technologies in STEM education in middle schools through this ITEST strategies project. Middle school students attend summer workshops to learn about 3D modeling and design of virtual worlds, teachers join the students during the second week of workshops to learn about 3D technologies and how they can be implemented in the curriculum. Regional experts share real world problems with teachers and students to generate possibilities for development of a 3D immersive world. Students serving as technical experts and teachers as curriculum and instruction experts then team to develop applications of virtual technologies for STEM instruction over the course of the project. The goals of the above activities are to engage teachers in continuous STEM learning, interest students in pursuing STEM careers, and preparing students with the skills necessary to succeed in STEM.

This project is based in educational literature and in a pilot study with students in sixth grade using 3D immersive technology to communicate information on explorers and exploration. The literature and the findings point to students improving engagement, communication, collaboration, use of information tools, STEM knowledge gain, and creating diverse communities of learners working on solutions to real-life problems. STEM content is expanded in this project by adding experts in science, technology, and engineering to the leadership team.

Formative and summative evaluation of the objectives of the project is guided by a series of questions and data and evidence is collected using both quantitative and qualitative methods.

POR.DRECONTENT:
STEM and ICT Instructional Worlds: The 3D Experience (STEM-ICT 3D) was funded by the National Science Foundation Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program. The intent of the project was to inspire middle school students to pursue studies and careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics - particularly information and communication technology (ICT) fields - as well as prepare students with the skills necessary to succeed in STEM education and careers.  The initiative was implemented by the Virtual World Consortium composed of Appalachian State University and Clemson University in partnership with Davie, Catawba, and Ashe County Schools in North Carolina, Oconee and Pickens County Schools in South Carolina, the Appalachian State University Mathematics and Science Education Center (MSEC), the North Carolina Department of Environment and Natural Resources (NC DENR), and Qwaq/Teleplace.

STEM-ICT 3D incorporated a series of activities that provided an engaging, safe environment for middle school students and teachers to explore STEM concepts within 3D immersive virtual worlds. Rising 7th grade students attended face-to-face workshops in the summer. During the first week of the STEM-ICT 3D Summer Academy, the students learned 3D virtual world modeling and design using Google Sketch-up and Qwaq/Teleplace. Seventh grade teachers then joined their students during the second week of the summer workshops at which time students served as the technical experts while the teachers learned the pedagogy for using 3D virtual worlds. Teachers and students collaboratively developed STEM-based learning projects for use in a 3D immersive virtual environment. After the Summer Academy, students and teachers returned to their respective schools and implemented their projects during the academic school year.

Over the four years of the program, 48 students and 75 teachers from North and South Carolina participated in the project activities beginning in June 2009 and continuing through the summer of 2012. The groups of teachers and students joined the program at different points in time. Program activities differed slightly across the three years, with Year 1 and Year 2 consisting of face- to-face professional development for participating teachers, a summer workshop for students, follow-up virtual professional development, ongoing contact from the STEM-ICT project staff, and a student virtual Tech Team started in 2011 that involved students who had attended the summer workshops. Year 3 involved STEM-ICT 3D students and teachers providing a Virtual World Conference for 28 educators in North and South Carolina. Year 4 activities provided additional opportunities for growth and development for the Cohort 1 and 2 teachers and students who were interested. These activities were supported by the program, but led by the educators themselves.

Student and teacher participants created a total of 47 collaborative, 3D immersive virtual environments to be used for STEM instruction in The 3rd Dimension virtual organization. The student-as-teacher-dynamic remained a consistent feature of program activities and was regarded highly by both students and educators.  Students reported that this program component and being viewed as helpers to other teachers motivated them to stay involved in the program. Parents of the 16 students who remained involved in the program after participation in one of the initial Summer Academies reported that their student’s interest in STEM and STEM careers increased overall and that their children’s involvement in the program motivated them to pursue additional STEM-related activities.
